hackathon-description-text: “Get Your Bot On” (GYBO) is a 34-hour hackathon focused on the design and prototyping of innovative ideas and solutions in robotics. Each team is given basic hardware to build a robot and supported by mentors and technical experts to ensure their demo is ready for judging on the final day (Sunday).

hackathon-judges.judge-role: Venture Lead, Cleantech and Physical Sciences, MaRS Discovery District

hackathon-eligibility:
We require participants work in groups of at least 3. Each team will receive a basic hardware kit.
Children under 12 must register with a parent or guardian as a family team.
hackathon-requirements: Each team will present on stage at MaRS on Sunday September 13, 2015 2-4pm.  In order to be elligible for any prize category the team must demo at the hackathon.
hackathon-rules:
There are only 5 rules for all robots that will be built:
Note that you are welcome to bring any materials you wish to the hackathon (as long as they are safe of course) but the assembly of your robot must happen at the hackathon.

hackathon-prizes.prize-content: A kit with Smart LED bulbs and networking equipment so you can control your lighting from your mobile device. Capable of millions of colours.

hackathon-prizes.prize-title: 1 hour of laser cutting time and free set up fee

hackathon-prizes.prize-content: A sensor kit for beginners to use with your Arduino.
A paper notebook that syncs to the cloud. Check it out at:

hackathon-location-google-maps: https://maps.google.com/?q=101 College Street, Toronto, ON M5G 1L7, Canada

hackathon-judging-criteria.judging-criterion: This category is for the most novel or compelling concept.
This category is for the best technically executed robot.
This category is for prototypes that have considered how humans will interact with the robot.
This category is for our family teams.

hackathon-location-address: 101 College Street, Toronto, ON M5G 1L7, Canada
hackathon-description-header: Imagine and build robots for healthier people, homes, schools, workplaces, play and the environment.
